Sine of the Students

Author: Zehao Zhang
Date: October 13, 2025

Model

Students

There are two students, xxx and yyy. Both must attend two courses indexed by j∈{1,2}j \in \{1, 2\}j∈{1,2}. Each student chooses an intensity ri∈[0,1]r_i \in [0, 1]ri​∈[0,1] and an angle φi∈[0,π/2]φ_i \in [0, π/2]φi​∈[0,π/2]. Their efforts are parameterized by the unit quarter-circle

(ei1,ei2)=ri(cos⁡φi,sin⁡φi),ei12+ei22≤1.(e_{i1}, e_{i2}) = r_i (\cos φ_i, \sin φ_i), \qquad e_{i1}^2 + e_{i2}^2 \le 1. (ei1​,ei2​)=ri​(cosφi​,sinφi​),ei12​+ei22​≤1.

Course outcomes equal effort, so yij=eijy_{ij} = e_{ij}yij​=eij​. Student xxx only cares about how far he can reach on the xxx-axis, while student yyy only values the yyy-axis. Both students try to avoid triggering the policy penalty defined below. We focus on cases where the budget binds, so ri=1r_i = 1ri​=1.

Lecturers

There are two lecturers, one per course. The outcome gap across students in course jjj is Δj≡maxi∈{x,y}yij−mini∈{x,y}yijΔ_j ≡ max_{i \in \{x, y\}} y_{ij} - min_{i \in \{x, y\}} y_{ij}Δj​≡maxi∈{x,y}​yij​−mini∈{x,y}​yij​. Each lecturer becomes extremely upset if the gap exceeds a threshold k∈(0,1)k \in (0, 1)k∈(0,1). Formally, the lecturer's utility is 000 when Δj<kΔ_j < kΔj​<k and −∞-∞−∞ otherwise.

Real-world motivation. Many universities moderate large within-class spreads: wide dispersions can trigger exam-board scrutiny (second marking, written justifications, or re-marking), while tighter spreads pass without comment. Instructors therefore focus on keeping the outcome gap below a trigger kkk, which our utility captures parsimoniously.

Director

A director cares about the lecturers' welfare while minimizing distortions to students' efforts. To prevent large outcome gaps, she imposes minimum requirements cj≥0c_j ≥ 0cj​≥0 in each course. If any student iii achieves yij<cjy_{ij} < c_jyij​<cj​ in any course jjj, that student's utility drops to −∞-∞−∞.

Analysis

Pre-AI Age

Students xxx and yyy would ideally choose outcomes (1,0)(1, 0)(1,0) and (0,1)(0, 1)(0,1) respectively, but such extremes violate the lecturers' tolerance for gaps. Thanks to the structure of the setup, a minimal policy that satisfies the lecturers' requirement exists and is illustrated in Figure 1.

Post-AI Age

Suppose AI substantially improves productivity only in course 1 (efforts along the xxx-axis become more efficient). The blue region in Figure 2 indicates pre-AI efforts and outcomes. If the director merely raises the minimum requirement c1c_1c1​ on the xxx-axis, AI benefits student xxx but harms student yyy, who must reallocate effort away from the preferred course 2. The director could instead raise c2c_2c2​ to mitigate this disparity.

Figure 1: Pre-AI minimal policy.
Figure 2: Post-AI minimal policy.
